issues.description: The Person class constructor visibility differs between the template and the solution and conflicts with how Person is instantiated elsewhere in the code. In the template the no-arg constructor is public (allowing instantiation from other packages), while in the solution the constructor is package-private (no modifier). Client code (e.g. PersonScene and other client classes) instantiate Person with new Person(), which requires a public constructor. The package-private constructor in the solution therefore contradicts the usage in the client and would prevent or confuse instantiation across packages/modules.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Person no-argument constructor public in the common model (restore `public Person() {}`) so that client and other packages can instantiate Person using `new Person()`. This keeps the template, problem description, and solution consistent and avoids cross-package instantiation issues.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) says "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter" while both the template and solution implementations of PersonController use `Consumer<List<Person>>`. This is an unintended identifier/entity mismatch (Note vs Person) for the same conceptual parameter and can confuse students about the expected type and which entity the consumer receives.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>). For example, change the line to: "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter, which has to be called after a response is received — this consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter."
